The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" includes anti-counterfeiting provisions such as the prohibition against trafficking in counterfeit components under Section 2318 of title 18, United States Code. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels or packaging for various types of works, with penalties of fines or up to 5 years imprisonment. It defines an 'illicit label' as a genuine certificate or licensing document used to verify works, and prohibits distribution without authorization or falsification of such labels. The Act prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels or packaging for various works, defining 'illicit label' as a genuine certificate used for verification. It prohibits distribution without authorization or falsification of such labels. The Act prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels or packaging for copyrighted works, including sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, visual art, and documentation or packaging. The Act prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels or packaging for copyrighted works, including sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, visual art, and documentation or packaging. Amendments include adding civil remedies for copyright owners injured by violations, allowing them to bring civil actions in court. The Act allows for civil actions in court to prevent or restrain violations of copyright infringement, including granting injunctions, impounding infringing articles, and awarding attorney fees, costs, damages, and profits to the injured party. The Act allows for civil actions in court to prevent or restrain copyright infringement violations. In such cases, the injured party may be awarded reasonable attorney fees, costs, actual damages, additional profits, or statutory damages. Actual damages include the value of the infringed works and any profits attributable to the violation. The court calculates actual damages in copyright infringement cases by multiplying the value of the infringed works by the number of copies involved. The value is determined by the retail value of authorized sound recordings or musical works. In copyright infringement cases, actual damages are calculated by multiplying the retail value of authorized copies of the infringed works by the number of copies involved. The retail value is based on the type of copyrighted work, such as sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, pictorial/graphic/sculptural works, or visual art. The injured party may choose to receive statutory damages instead of actual damages and profits for copyright infringement, ranging from $2,500 to $25,000 per violation. The court can triple the damages for subsequent violations within 3 years of a previous judgment. The statute limits civil actions for copyright infringement to be commenced within 3 years of discovering the violation. A conforming amendment is made to section 2318 regarding trafficking in counterfeit labels. SEC. 103. OTHER RIGHTS NOT AFFECTED. The amendments made by this title do not affect liability under certain sections of Title 17, United States Code, and do not apply to electronic transmissions of genuine or counterfeit documents under Title 18, United States Code. The amendments made by this title do not affect fair use of genuine certificates, licensing documents, registration cards, or similar labeling components under Title 17, United States Code. TITLE II--FRAUDULENT ONLINE IDENTITY SANCTIONS

SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE.

This title may be cited as the ``Fraudulent Online Identity Sanctions Act''.

SEC. 202. AMENDMENT TO TRADEMARK ACT OF 1946. Section 35 of the Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include a new subsection (e) which establishes a rebuttable presumption of willful violation if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name used in connection with the violation. This does not limit what may be considered a willful violation under this section. SEC. 203. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 17, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 504(c) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name used in connection with the infringement. This does not limit what can be considered willful infringement under this subsection. The term 'domain name' is defined as in section 45 of the Act for registration and protection. The term 'domain name' is defined in section 45 of the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 204. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. Amendment to Title 18, United States Code includes a sentencing enhancement for individuals convicted of a felony offense involving false registration and use of a domain name. The maximum imprisonment for the offense will be doubled or increased by 7 years. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines to ensure strict penalties for individuals convicted of felony offenses carried out online using a domain name with false contact information. The United States Sentencing Commission will enhance penalties for felony offenses committed online using a domain name with false contact information. This includes providing false information to domain name registrars or authorities during registration, maintenance, or renewal of the domain name. The "Trademark Act of 1946" (15 U.S.C. 1127) provides for the registration and protection of trademarks used in commerce, in accordance with international conventions. SEC. 205 of the Trademark Act of 1946 ensures that rights of free speech and press are not affected by domain name registration. It also clarifies that courts have discretion in determining damages for intellectual property infringement and terms of imprisonment. Additionally, SEC. 301 amends the location of court proceedings in Colorado. Section 85 of title 28, United States Code, amended to include "Colorado Springs," after "Boulder,".
